Fiction
HONEYMOON, by James Patterson and Howard Roughan. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) An F.B.I. agent who is investigating a beautiful and mysterious woman finds himself becoming obsessed with her.

THE BROKER, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) The C.I.A. arranges a presidential pardon for a power broker who may know crucial secrets, laying a trap for the foreign intelligence service that wants him dead.

THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95; special illustrated edition, $35.) A murder at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to the discovery of a secret society.

THE FIVE PEOPLE YOU MEET IN HEAVEN, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $19.95.) An old man who died while trying to rescue a little girl from danger discovers that all will be explained to him in the afterlife.
PRINCE OF FIRE, by Daniel Silva. (Putnam, $25.95.) Gabriel Allon, an art restorer and an occasional spy for the Israeli secret service, investigates a terrorist bombing in Rome.

SURVIVOR IN DEATH, by J. D. Robb. (Putnam, $23.95.) In 2059, Lt. Eve Dallas has an eyewitness to the brutal murder of a family: the sole survivor, a 9-year-old girl; by Nora Roberts, writing pseudonymously.
PREP, by Curtis Sittenfeld. (Random House, $21.95.) A scholarship student from South Bend, Ind., encounters a world of privilege when she attends an expensive boarding school in Massachusetts.
BLOOD MEMORY, by Greg Iles. (Scribner, $24.95.) A forensic scientist probes recent killings as well as a decades-old crime -- the murder of her father.
*THE FORGOTTEN MAN, by Robert Crais. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The Los Angeles private eye Elvis Cole searches for the truth about his father.
STATE OF FEAR, by Michael Crichton. (HarperCollins, $27.95.) Reverse eco-terrorists create natural disasters to convince the public that global warming is real.
THE KILLING CLUB, by Marcie Walsh with Michael Malone. (Hyperion, $19.95.) A police detective investigates the deaths of friends of hers from high school.
CONVICTION, by Richard North Patterson. (Random House, $25.95.) A lawyer comes to believe that her client -- who is on death row -- may be innocent.
CHAINFIRE, by Terry Goodkind. (Tor/Tom Doherty, $29.95.) The 10th volume of the ''Sword of Truth'' fantasy series.

ME & EMMA, by Elizabeth Flock. (Mira, $17.95.) Living with a drunken stepfather in an impoverished home in North Carolina, an 8-year-old girl tries to create a new life for herself and her younger sister.
IRELAND, by Frank Delaney. (HarperCollins, $26.95.) Inspired by an itinerant storyteller, a boy immerses himself in the history and mythology of his country.

Nonfiction
BLINK, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) The author of ''The Tipping Point'' explores the importance of hunch and instinct to the workings of the mind.
JUICED, by Jose Canseco. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $25.95.) The former slugger talks about his life in baseball and, especially, his use of steroids.
COLLAPSE, by Jared Diamond. (Viking, $29.95.) A historical investigation, by the author of ''Guns, Germs, and Steel,'' into why some societies succeed while others fail.
MEN IN BLACK, by Mark R. Levin. (Regnery, $27.95.) A conservative commentator enumerates ways in which ''the Supreme Court is destroying America.'' (+)
DISNEYWAR, by James B. Stewart. (Simon & Schuster, $29.95.) A two-decade history of corporate infighting, by the author of ''Den of Thieves'' and ''Blood Sport.''
AMERICA (The BOOK), by Jon Stewart, Ben Karlin, David Javerbaum et al. (Warner, $24.95.) ''The Daily Show'' offers an illustrated parody of a civics textbook.
SECRETS & MYSTERIES OF THE WORLD, by Sylvia Browne. (Hay House, $19.95.) The self-proclaimed psychic tries to explain the inexplicable.

*GOD'S POLITICS, by Jim Wallis. (HarperSanFrancisco, $24.95.) An evangelical Christian argues that Democrats must ''take back the faith'' and not allow conservative Republicans to hijack the Bible. (+)
PERFECT MADNESS, by Judith Warner. (Riverhead, $23.95.) An examination of modern motherhood and ''the age of anxiety.''
102 MINUTES, by Jim Dwyer and Kevin Flynn. (Times Books/Holt, $26.) Two journalists at The New York Times describe people's struggle to survive inside the World Trade Center on Sept. 11.
WINNING THE FUTURE, by Newt Gingrich. (Regnery, $27.95.) The former speaker of the House proposes a 21st-century ''Contract With America.'' (+)
TORI AMOS: Piece by Piece, by Tori Amos and Ann Powers. (Broadway, $23.95.) A memoir by the singer-songwriter.
SMASHED, by Koren Zailckas. (Viking, $21.95.) A young woman recalls her excessive drinking throughout high school and college.
CONFESSIONS OF AN ECONOMIC HIT MAN, by John Perkins. (Berrett-Koehler, $24.95.) A former employee of an international consulting firm denounces the American global empire and its ''corporatocracy.''
THE CASE FOR DEMOCRACY, by Natan Sharansky with Ron Dermer. (PublicAffairs, $26.95.) The former Soviet dissident and political prisoner assays ''the power of freedom to overcome tyranny and terror.''
*WITNESS, by Amber Frey. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $25.95.) A memoir by the California massage therapist who testified against Scott Peterson.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Feb. 26, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
Editors' Choice Other recent books of particular interest
THE ROAD TO REALITY: A Complete Guide to the Laws of the Universe, by Roger Penrose. (Knopf, $40.) From Pythagoras to string theory, a big thinker's rendition of the big picture.
GOD LIVES IN ST. PETERSBURG: And Other Stories, by Tom Bissell. (Pantheon, $20.) Mordant short stories, mostly about Americans in Central Asia losing their cultural reflexes.
THE COURAGE CONSORT: Three Novellas, by Michel Faber. (Harcourt, $23.) Stylish, eerie fictions about baffled people in opaque situations.
POL POT: Anatomy of a Nightmare, by Philip Short. (John Macrae/Holt, $30.) A journalist's searching biography of the commander of the Cambodian killing fields in the late 1970's.

THE ORIENTALIST: Solving the Mystery of a Strange and Dangerous Life, by Tom Reiss. (Random House, $25.95.) The bold writer and impostor Lev Nussimbaum (Kurban Said) (Essad Bey) and his lives from 1905 to 1942.
WHERE SHALL I WANDER, by John Ashbery. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $22.95.) New poems from our great living poet of the interior landscape.
DR. KING'S REFRIGERATOR: And Other Bedtime Stories, by Charles Johnson. (Scribner, $20.) Religion, philosophy and African magic realism enhance these short fiction performances.
CAST OF SHADOWS, by Kevin Guilfoile. (Knopf, $24.95.) A joke-free thriller about cloning by a writer best known as a humorist.
AL-JAZEERA: The Inside Story of the Arab News Channel That Is Challenging the West, by Hugh Miles. (Grove, $24.) A gadfly in Arab lands that became the bane of the Bush people.

ESTER AND RUZYA: How My Grandmothers Survived Hitler's War and Stalin's Peace, by Masha Gessen. (Dial, $24.) A fine journalist's account of two indomitable women who did more than survive; they kept their humanity.
ASTRO TURF: The Private Life of Rocket Science, by M. G. Lord. (Walker, $24.) A history and a cultural criticism of the machismo-soaked universe of her father's lab at Caltech.
The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books
